title: Pwll Du Circular Walk Route

nearby.description: Mumbles to Langland and Caswell Bay Walk

images.title: Nick Andrews / Pwlldu Bay looking towards Pwlldu Head
images.caption: Pwlldu Bay looking towards Pwlldu Head. National Trust owned. Used to be a site for limestone mining. This lovely cove is backed by extensive woodland, and is stunning.

images.title: Cliffs and slopes on the Southgate Coast by peter robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Limestone Cliffs at Pwlldu Head
images.caption: Limestone Cliffs at Pwlldu Head

images.title: Deep Slade near Southgate by peter robinson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Deep Slade near Southgate

images.title: Marion Phillips / Pwlldu Pebbles
images.caption: Pwlldu Pebbles. The stream that flows down this valley is dammed up by this great bank of pebbles to form a black pool, or pwll du. The stream has no mouth and just seeps through the bank into the sea. The cottages were built for quarrymen who quarried limestone from the cliff out of sight to the left of the photograph. The limestone was dragged down the slope and loaded onto boats and taken across the Severn estuary to Devon.

images.title: Footbridge near the Bishopston Valley by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footbridge near the Bishopston Valley

description: This circular walk explores the area around the National Trust's Pwll Du Bay on the Gower Peninsula. The beautiful bay and beach are regarded as something of a Gower hidden gem. There is no immediate parking so it's a peaceful and secluded spot to visit. The route starts at the Southgate National Trust car park just west of the bay. You can then follow footpaths east along the coast to Pwll Du Head and then on to the beach at Pwll Du Bay. There's some steps down to the beach which means 'Black Pool' in English. The route then heads through the delightful Bishopston Valley where you can enjoy some shady woodland trails, river paths and secret little caves. The route then heads west from here through Lockway Wood to return to the car park.
